(First in a series of four broadcasts on the Italian parliament In relation
to the January political crisis)
This la Graham Hovey, sending along another radio Letter from Italy under
the dateline* Rome. These programs are produced for the national Association
of Educational Broadcasters with the cooperation of Radiotelevisions Italians.
The guide books say that the Palace of Montecitorio was begun in the year
1650 by the great Roman architect and sculptor, Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini.
If you have visited Rome you probably will recall Montecitorio. Its
original front is located almost in the heart of downtown Rome, Just off the
Piazza Colonna. It Is next door to the Chigl palace, which houses the Italian
foreign ministry. Its most imposing exterior landmarks on this original front
are a familiar but always beautiful type of bell tower and a huge clock that
face the square which io named for the palacej a square that has at its center
one of dome13 many obelisks.
At its other end, Montecitorio has another imposing front — you*d have
to call it another "front/’ even if the term seems contradictory. And this
second "front" is dominated by a long and broad flight of steps that ends in the
Piazza del Parlamenio — Parliament square.
This square gets its name because the Palace of Montecitorio houses the
Italian Chamber of Deputies — the more important house of the Italian parlia¬
ment. Italians use the word "Montealtorlo" in political conversation in the
way we Americans use the expression "Capitol Hill/1 or the way in which the
British use the word, "Westminster."
Xou would know immediately what an American meant if he told you to ex¬
pect plenty of fireworks on Capitol Hill over the -iricker amendment. In the
same way, if an Italian says it will be a week "molto movimentata" at Mon tec 1-
torio, he means that the debate in the Chamber of Deputies will be fiery and
agitated.
Well, the last week in January certainly was "molto moviiaentata" at the
Palace of Montecitorio. It was the week In which the Chamber decided the fate
of the government constituted on January 18 by Amintore Fanfani. It was the
week in which the Chamber, by striking down Fanfani, left Italy without a gov¬
ernment for the second time in a month, and thus reopened the political crisis
which started with the resignation of Premier Giuseppe Pella on January 5•
Article 94 of the Italian constitution requires a new government to pre¬
sent Itself to the Chamber and the Senate for a vote of confidence within 10
days after its formation. So, on Tuesday, January 26, Signor Fanfani formally
presented hie cabinet and his program, first to the Chamber and then to the
Senate, which meets about half a mile southwest of Montecitorio in the Madams
palace.
Then the Senate adjourned to permit the Chamber to act first. And for
four long parliamentary sessions on consecutive days, Fanfani and his cabinet
sat at the ministerial bench in the well of the Chamber and heard themselves
worked over by political orators ranging from far Left to far Right. The vote
of rejection for the Fanfani government came in mid-afternoon of Jaturday,
January 30.
Hot for a long time have ordinary Italian citizens been so interested In
a debate at Montecitorio.
